Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Next-Gen Clustering: Fast and Accurate Ways to Cluster Proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
DNA sequencing technology has decreased the cost and increased the speed of genome sequencing, and this has led to an exponential growth in the availability of sequenced genomes. In order to take full advantage of the situation, researchers must have easy-to-use but powerful software tools. Unfortunately, it has been a struggle for providers of open-source software to keep pace with the immense volumes of biological data generated on a daily basis. As a result, many researchers are using tools for tasks the software was not meant to perform resulting in less than optimal results. Suitable open-source software tools are needed to process the quantities of genome data and obtain the knowledge needed for scientific breakthroughs. The intellectual merit of the proposed project is that it will fill one significant void, the need for a software program that can be used to cluster millions of protein sequences from sequenced genomes quickly and accurately using cloud computing. From these protein clusters, a phylogenomics approach can be used to predict the function of uncharacterized proteins. Several versions of the software tool pClust have already been developed, and results obtained are far superior to those generated by any other means. For this work a version of pClust will be developed for use in the cloud and with support for incremental clustering. In addition pClust will be used to cluster proteins from all available whole genome sequences for the entire bacterial phylum Proteobacteria (approximately 1770 species presently). This will be the most comprehensive study of the Proteobacteria phylum ever and will represent a scale that has never as yet been achieved.

The broader impacts of this project will occur in several different areas. When made available via cloud computing and a user-friendly graphical user interface, the parallel configuration of the pClust program will allow scientists worldwide to analyze thousands of genomes at once, quickly and accurately clustering all the proteins within the genomes. Deployment of this software tool will have a significant impact on discoveries in science and medicine. In terms of education, both graduate and undergraduate students will be trained. Emphasis will be placed on recruiting and engaging female students into this interdisciplinary project, and the project team will participate in annual outreach programs to middle and high school students. Key research findings originating from this project will be published in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. Also, the software tools developed as part of this project will be published as open source at Google Code, and the results of the clustering, including the protein clusters themselves, phylogenetic trees, phylogenetic profiles, and percentage agreement among the phylogenetic profiles will be made freely available on the WSU School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science's Bioinformatics and Computational Biology Web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because of the rapid increase in the number of complete genomes/proteomes available in public databases, this project focused on improving methods for grouping protein sequences into clusters based on their similarity.  We also used protein clusters to answer several questions about bacteria.

Most methods used to cluster protein sequences are based on the alignment of pairs of sequences; this becomes computationally expensive for very large numbers of sequences.  Thus, we developed an alignment-free method called NADDA for clustering conserved regions in protein sequences.  Our approach was based on the frequency of k-mers, that is, the repetition of short sequences of the same amino acids of a given length.  This led to the development of an alignment-free technique for clustering protein domains using min-hashing which is a way to quickly estimate how similar two sets are.  Together with NADDA, this approach allows the complete annotation of protein sequences.

In addition to our novel alignment-free approach, we continued work on our original pClust method for clustering protein sequences which, while based on the alignment of sequences, is fast, accurate, stable, and, importantly, mature and well tested.  We developed a graphical user interface (GUI) that combines the two steps of the method and makes pClust easy to use.  In conjunction with this development, we performed an exhaustive study of the pClust parameters to ascertain how changing them affects results and, hence, which parameters are best to use for a given application.

We used a parallel version of pClust on a high performance computing platform to cluster more than 8.7M protein sequences deduced from 2,307 Proteobacterial genomes, obtaining more than 2,400 non-singleton clusters.  Then based on published results for a minimal genome, we chose four essential proteins to examine questions of whether these essential proteins were conserved in all the Proteobacterial organisms represented by our 2,307 genomes and if not, why not.  Over the course of our study, we discovered several annotation issues plaguing the NCBI database.

We used the GUI version of pClust to perform a comparative genomics study of tickborne pathogens to determine whether ticks started transmitting diseases to hosts at a given point in time or at many different times over the course of evolution.  In this same study, we created a phylogenetic tree of the tickborne pathogens from the clusters and compared it to that of one in the literature.

Our work with bacteria has expanded, and we're now considering all bacterial phyla currently represented in the NCBI database.  We are exploring the relationships among the bacteria and asking questions based on clustering protein sequences deduced from whole genomes such as what phylum is the oldest.

All our results have been published either in open-access journals such as PLoS ONE, BMC Bioinformatics, and BMC Genomics or else in the Proceedings of an ACM meeting.  Several more refereed journal publications are stil to be pubished as a result of this project.  All software is available to the public at github or bitbucket via our website http://www.eecs.wsu.edu/bcb.  Two students have obtained their PhDs under this project, one of whom is currently a postdoctoral research associate at the Cleveland Clinic and the other of whom is a research scientist at Raytheon.  Another student has partially completed her PhD under this project.  Two of the three students supported by this project are females, and one is the first wheelchair-bound student with cerebral palsy to have completed a PhD in Computer Science.
